The name Parakou, is derived from the Dendi word meaning "La ville de toute le monde" which means "The city of everyone". It is one of the ethnically diverse cities in Benin that include Bariba, Dendi, Somba, Fon, Mina, Berba, Djerma, Ibo, Yoruba, Hausa, Kabrais, Warma, Fula and Tuareg.
National highway RNIE 2, Benin's main highway, passes by here. It connects with

in the south, continuing towards the border with Niger.

Parakou is the northern rail terminus and although the tracks are in a pretty bad shape it is possible to travel from Cotonou here. Departures are at 8:30AM from Cotonou on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. On it's way up the country the train also stops at Bohicon, just outside UNESCO heritage site and royal city

, before arriving in Parakou at 7PM. Tickets starts at CFA 5600 for first class.

If you are travelling in a group, a more leisurly way of reaching Parakou from Cotonou would be by the privately run tourist train

. Composed of vintage railroad cars from the 1920s and offering both dinner, a bar and hammocks for afternoon naps. The train operates on request and prices begins at CFA 400,000 and can accommodate up to 20 persons.

value: name=Musée en Plein Air de Parakou
content=An outdoor museum with traditional houses of the local Batanou peoples.
has its own zoo with alligators, turtles, warthogs, a small gazelle, and various birds.

, one of the largest in Benin, is a must when visiting Parakou. With more then a thousand vendors you'll find anything from fine rugs to fake DVDs.

value: has works of art for sale including carved wooden masks, wall-hangings and jewelry.
content=Serves generously portions of mainly African cuisine.
